user.biography: What’s it take to create a @natgeo photograph?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Photos by @davillasana / For an upcoming @natgeo story, writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) and I followed up with two transgender women from Honduras who recently migrated to the United States. Having documented the migration of Kataleya Nativi Baca and Alexa Smith since 2018, seeing them achieve a large part of their dreams was moving. At the same time, however, new sets of issues have been daunting and difficult for them to navigate. 

Due to unstable living conditions in Virginia, Kataleya spent nearly all her savings to live with someone in Texas she’d known online for three years. Though José didn’t pick her up at the airport when she arrived, forcing her to sleep in the baggage claim area, she eventually made it to his apartment in Houston where Aurora joined us.

These images are from our time with Kataleya in her new daily life routines, such as cleaning (while dancing!) the apartment when José and his roommates worked. Though this new prospect of living in Texas seemed promising, it didn’t last long—stay tuned for our story to learn more about Kataleya’s journey.

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa

node.text:
Photo by @lauredutruy / Élodie is sitting with her children in their bungalow as the family is spending holidays on a campsite in Brittany, western France in August 2021. 
In 2008, the single-mother adopted her first child Nathanaël, then Magdaléna and Abellino. They were all born with Down Syndrome. 

The children have textbooks to work on over the summer holiday to help them retain information learned over the preceding school year, which has been challenging due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Here Élodie is seen helping her 13-year-old son Nathanaël doing mathematics by showing him how to count with hands clapping.

This photograph is part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down Syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disability

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 13, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and indoor.

node.text:
Photos by @davillasana / Since 2018, I’ve followed the journeys of Kataleya Nativi Baca and Alexa Smith, who were pushed to flee Honduras due to transphobia and violence. From the circumstances forcing them north, through Central America and Mexico to the United States, they’ve faced unthinkable challenges. 

Recently I teamed up with writer Aurora Almendral (@aurora_alm) for a @natgeo story about how Kataleya and Alexa are adjusting to their new lives in the United States. 

While Kataleya found a room to rent in Virginia with a friend, their transphobic landlord insulted them on a regular basis, threatening to call the police if they didn’t leave by the end of the month. Kataleya decided to move to Texas into the apartment of a Honduran man she’d known online for three years. Hearing of the less expensive living conditions and with the prospect of more stability, she felt it was a more secure option.

These are some images of Kataleya’s hectic moving day, treasured items she took with her, and the beginning of her unexpected journey to Texas. Many thanks as well to @womenphotograph for supporting part of this project. 

#lgbtqia #transwomen #migration #resilience #usa

node.text:
Photos by Arturo Rodriguez @arturorguezdotcom / La Palma Island, par of the Canary Islands, in the southernmost region of Spain is a small island that is suffering less than other islands of the archipelago because a large part of the local economy is based around agriculture and not the tourism. There used to be many cargo ships transporting food between the Canary Islands and the European continent but last year, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, shipments slowed dramatically. The primary sector has suffer the consequences from this but is now recovering faster than the tourism industry.

This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists. #CanaryIslands #Tenerife #Spain #Covid-19

node.text: Photos & Video of @lynseyaddario / As historic fires sweep across California, I was on the ground with @natgeo documenting @calfire firefighters who are working tirelessly to contain the fire and to protect the towns and homes around Lake Tahoe. After twelve 18-hour days, I could barely think straight. I can only imagine how the firefighters and emergency workers are holding up during the peak of fire season. @u.s.forestservice @calfire #caldorfire #dixiefire photos by @sashwaburrous & @calfire

node.text: Photo by @amr.alfiky / The statue of Confederate General Robert E. Lee was sawed in half for easier transport after its removal from the plinth on Wednesday morning. The statue, which weighs 12 tons, was erected in 1890 and was the last Confederate statue on Monument Avenue in Richmond, Virginia to be taken down after the issue was debated in the courts for over a year.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 08, 2021. May be an image of outdoors.

node.text: Photos by @amr.alfiky / The 12-ton statue of Robert E. Lee that stood 6 stories tall on Monument Avenue in Richmond, Virginia was removed today. Erected in 1890, the monument was used to attract elite, white homeowners to the area, keeping Black homeowners out. It quickly became a symbol of white supremacy and was recently used as a space for protest following the murder of George Floyd in 2020. People watched on as the statue was removed. In the last photo, Devon Henry, owner of the construction company that removed the Robert E. Lee statue, hugs his mom, Freda Thorton, after the statue was removed.

#tokyo #landscapes

node.text:
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero / The Alte Münze in central Berlin served as one of Germany’s official coin factories from 1936 to 2005. Prior to the pandemic the massive industrial building served as a venue for electronic music events. With a forced closure they used the time to redevelop and reimagine the venue, improving spaces for electronic music parties as well as adding exhibition space for artists, cultural workers, and young Berlin creatives. The first exhibition called 'Corona Culture' will have over 150 artists throughout its newly transformed space. This is an example of one of the pieces, named ‘Pandemic Explosion' by artist Eddi Egal with Oskar Kish. It is a kinetic fire sculpture regarding the pandemic exploding world, where by inserting a 1 euro coin the viewer can make the world turn again.

Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see more of the world through my lens. The above video was taken in Berlin, Germany on assignment with @natgeo documenting Berlin’s electronic music scene, its importance in society here and how the industry has adapted to the Covid-19 Pandemic.

#berlin #electronicmusic #berlinreboot #altemuenzeberlin #coronaculture

node.text:
Photo by @rubensalgadoescudero / The nightlife industry in Germany's capital city is its third largest economy, bringing in over $1.5 billion dollars in 2018. Part of the heart of this scene are the DJs whose lives were turned upside down during the pandemic. While people were stuck in their homes streaming services popped up to bring their favorite DJs music straight to them, and Berlin's iconic Watergate club decided to bring the music straight from the dance floor. In this image taken on August 30, 2021, German/Nigerian DJ and producer JAMIIE plays a streaming set inside the club. JAMIIE is one of Watergate’s resident DJs and due to the pandemic lost all work there. She played the clubs first streaming event on the platform United We Stream, an international cultural platform that advocates the preservation of diverse club culture and its values through cross-genre and interdisciplinary streams. Watergate has had over 30 live streamings since the pandemic began, as well as renting its space and equipment for many artists to record streams there as well. 

Follow me @rubensalgadoescudero to see more of the world through my lens. The above video was taken in Berlin, Germany on assignment with @natgeo documenting Berlin’s electronic music scene, its importance in society here and how the industry has adapted to the Covid-19 Pandemic.

Music - Elsewhere (UK) - Entwine

#berlin #electronicmusic #berlinreboot #watergateberlin #watergaterecords #jamiievibe

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Nat Geo in the Field on September 06, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Photo by @lauredutruy / Abellino is a 8-year-old boy who was born with Down syndrome. This photo was taken in western France in October 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic. Social distancing rules and the various phases of lockdown have limited physical stimulation, making the child’s development more difficult. Here Abellino is seen developing self-reliance through the little gestures of everyday life, such as putting on clothes by himself. 

As a baby, he was diagnosed with cardiopathy and underwent surgery which left that scar on his chest. Heart disease is common in children with Down syndrome.

This photograph is part of an ongoing story on how a family with three children with Down syndrome are getting through the pandemic in France. This work is supported by the @insidenatgeo COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists.

#downsyndrome #trisomy21 #disabilities
